posts.cooked:
Our team has been running SDS swerve modules for the past four seasonsâ€”both Mk4 and MK4â€”and they have been quite reliable. However, as we prepare for the upcoming seasons, we are seriously considering a switch.  

We are currently evaluating two options:  
1. WCP X2-ST  
2. SDS MK4N  

If you've used either model (or both), we'd greatly appreciate your input on the following aspects:  
- Durability and maintenance across multiple events  
- Driving feel and performance under defense  
- Encoder setupâ€”we're using CANcoders for absolute positioning  
- Packaging or mounting differences  
- Any "we wish we knew this earlier" experiences  

We're not making this decision lightlyâ€”itâ€™s based on a thorough evaluation of real-world value for performance, reliability, and maintenance.  

Thank you for any insights, pros and cons, or even CAD examples if youâ€™re willing to share!

The mk5 showcase at the championship was impressive. It stands notably smaller than the MK4 and offers support for a wider 2-inch tread via WCP swerve technology. Additionally, the Mk5 model features a swerve cover that protects both the gear unit and its bevel gears, preventing carpet from entering them.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: One thing that puts me off of SDS is the use of belts. Given the choice, Iâ€™d rather not have belts in my modules.

I donâ€™t believe there are any belts in the mk5. The image suggests a gear for steering, though itâ€™s challenging to tell because of the covering. There isnâ€™t a belt unless itâ€™s installed on this module, which hasnâ€™t been done yet.

posts.name: Duncan Macdonald
posts.cooked:
My swerve purchase decision tree:
- Is it griplock compatible?
- Can my existing modules/components be used as drop-in spare parts?
- Cost
- How many gear ratios come standard
- Weight
- Powder coating

posts.name: doruk bazan
posts.cooked: If you encounter financial difficulties, purchasing a Mk4i to Mk4n conversion kit may be advisable. If feasible, I recommend acquiring WCP modules instead, as they function more quickly than SDS modules and avoid belt-related issues such as breakage, which often occur with SDS modules. While the primary drawback of SDS modules is their higher cost, another challenge lies in their repair process, which tends to be more complex compared to SDS modules. Additionally, alternative solutions like cancoder are available.

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked: Okay, but to be fair, that belt is in such a low-load application (azimuth) that it really doesnâ€™t matter.

posts.name: doruk bazan
posts.cooked: Last year, the MK4i belt of the 9483 team broke. Frankly, the use of belts scares me just as much.

Jimmyy mentions that the belt in question operates in a low-load azimuth setup, stating that its performance doesn't significantly impact the system. However, the reality is that the belt experiences a higher load than initially perceived. This becomes evident when considering the operational dynamics of FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) swerve modules, which accelerate modules rapidly, resulting in extreme dynamic loads far exceeding initial assumptions. Additionally, the use of mk4-style pulleys with partial tooth engagement and a small pinion pulley does not adequately support HTD belts, contributing to shortened lifespan. Teams have indeed experienced belt breaks, further highlighting these inefficiencies.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I was talking to the guy at the SDS table at Champs and he talked about switching to a gear for MK5 because some teams don't use current limits. He said 2910 has never had any breakage issues with the belt in their whole time using them.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Hereâ€™s a refined version of your text, adhering to the specified requirements:

---

My swerve purchase decision tree focused on compatibility, functionality, and cost, including factors like griplock support, module adaptability, number of gear ratios, weight, and powder coating. However, my approach differs from others, particularly SDS Swerve, which had limitations in stock management reliability. After evaluating alternatives, I switched to WCP West Coast Products, which proved more reliable in meeting my needs effectively.

---

This version removes all HTML tags, condenses the content into a single paragraph, preserves key points, and ensures clarity and grammatical correctness.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: I can confirm that we tested two seasons using identical belts, and the failure occurred when a fastener locked the module, combined with our high current limits causing the belt to wear out. In my opinion, the SDIS product is highly effective.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I'm a big fan of the Swerve X, and my team intends to continue using it. However, having seen the MK5, I now believe it's the best choice. The MK5 offers many advantages in terms of serviceability, and its coverage will significantly reduce debris in the gears. That said, this is merely my opinion and doesn't factor in potential budget constraints, as the price of the MK5 has yet to be determined.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: This is correctâ€”a 10dp gear is driving now.

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: We used the Mk4n this season, and it worked exceptionally well, allowing us to integrate our elevator seamlessly into their setup thanks to the extra space available. However, since they have announced the Mk5s, if the budget doesnâ€™t cover it, I recommend considering the Mk4i-to-Mk4n conversion kit as an alternative solution.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: We started using SwerveX because that was what we could purchase within our required timeframe. We liked the corner-biased variant, which has been extremely reliable. The encoders we used when employing NEOs were picky, but Kraken addressed that issue. The primary maintenance involved periodically cleaning out the greasy debris from the "fuzz balls." If SDS has indeed resolved this concern, that certainly points in their favor.

posts.name: Nick Matthes
posts.cooked:
As a WCP X2ST user this season, this is one of the best modules weâ€™ve used. Durability and maintenance across multiple events driving feel and performance under defense encoder setup packaging or mounting differences any â€œwe wish we knew this earlierâ€ moments.

We had minimal maintenance across events basic grease and tread adjustments. The WCP molded tread this year received great reviews price point was excellent, easy to change, and provided strong traction during defense. We also appreciated the Throughbore encoders which performed exceptionally well.

Planning the chassis required considering the moduleâ€™s footprint, but it didnâ€™t exceed whatâ€™s typical for other modules on the market. One area for improvement would be having the module available earlier, allowing its use in more scenarios. 

Note: 33 is sponsored by WestCoast Products but these comments reflect our genuine feelings regardless of sponsorship.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: Iâ€™ve been using the MK4is for two years. The belt is never an issue. Actually, the whole module is solid, and Iâ€™ve never had any issues which werenâ€™t our fault. I wish they were smaller though; it does get tricky to design around them.

posts.name: Matt Golman
posts.cooked:
Mk4i modules are highly effective and do not hinder performance. If one consistently seeks the absolute best products available, they may need to frequently switch suppliers indefinitely.

We utilized X2T modules this year due to their superior wide tread design, compact form factor, increased wheelbase, and geared steering, which provide an noticeable enhancement compared to the Mk4i modules we previously used.

Before making decisions based solely on current information, consider that the Mk5 modules appear to represent only a slight improvement over WCP modules, primarily offering greater convenience in ratio adjustments. Additionally, the Mk5 features wider wheels, though the impact on performance remains uncertain.

posts.name: Lewis
posts.cooked: The modules make less of a difference compared to the motors and code. The next most critical factor is whether youâ€™ve read the manual and applied locktite and grease where necessary. In my opinion, considering its cost, the easiest path to achieving a controlled, low-battery drive is using C-TRE motors on both drive and steering, along with Pigeon 2, Canivore, and a Pro License. Additionally, incorporating a C-TRE Swerve Generator and Advantage Kit may streamline the process. After testing various combinationsâ€”such as WCP, REV, and SDS motorsâ€”and even all-Kraken setupsâ€”the methods involving REV or C-TRE motors proved significantly simpler.

data.title: SDS to WCP? Looking for Long-Term Swerve Advice
